0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-congress-idUSKCN11R2SF	Trump opposes plan for U.S. to cede internet oversight	"
By Dustin Volz
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump opposes a long-planned transition of oversight of the internet's technical management from the U.S. government to a global community of stakeholders
column2: his campaign said in a statement on Wednesday.Congress should block the handover
column3: scheduled to occur on Oct. 1
column4: ""or internet freedom will be lost for good
column5: since there will be no way to make it great again once it is lost
column7: national policy director for the Trump campaign
column8: said in a statement.Senator Ted Cruz of Texas
column9: a former presidential primary foe of Trump's who has refused to endorse the real estate developer
column10: has led a movement in Congress to block the transition
column11: arguing it could cede control of the internet itself to authoritarian regimes like Russia and China and threaten online freedom.

column1: Technical experts have said those claims are baseless
column2: and that a delay will backfire by undermining U.S. credibility in future international negotiations over internet standards and security.Publicly proposed in March 2014
column3: the transfer of oversight of the nonprofit Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers
column4: or ICANN
column5: is expected to go forward unless Congress votes to block the move.

column1: A vote to delay the transition may come as an amendment to a temporary spending bill that Congress must pass by Sept. 30 to prevent much of the federal government from shutting down. Congressional negotiators on Wednesday were working to finalize an agreement on the spending package.
Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton supports the Obama administration's planned transition to a global community of technologists
column2: civil society groups and internet users
column3: according to policy positions available on her campaign website.  (Reporting by Dustin Volz; Editing by Sandra Maler)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-kansas-education-idUSKCN11R2HW	Kansas argues against boost in school funding	"

Kansas sought on Wednesday to avoid a court ruling that could force the cash-strapped state to increase school funding by more than $1 billion.Lawyers for the state and for public school districts faced off before the Kansas Supreme Court in the latest chapter of a decades-long battle over equitable and adequate funding.Stephen McAllister
column2: the state's solicitor general
column3: argued that while Kansas may be spending less on education than some other states
column4: student achievement is improving.""Kansas is making excellent use of resources to do pretty well compared to the nation
column5: he told the justices.The state spends about $4 billion on schools
column6: but lawyers for the four districts suing the state claim another $430 million to $1.4 billion would be required to meet the state constitution's requirement for adequate funding.

column1: We're falling short and we're leaving massive numbers of kids behind
column2: said Alan Rupe
column3: an attorney for the districts.He asked the court to declare the system unconstitutional and give the state legislature some direction on achieving constitutionality and a full legislative session to come up with a new system.

column1: The justices did not indicate when they might rule.The adequacy question comes after the court ruled in June that Kansas had complied with its order to resolve inequities in educating students.

Kansas' budget is feeling the effects of actions taken by Republican Governor Sam Brownback and the legislature in recent years to cut corporate and other income taxes in hopes of helping the state compete with bordering Missouri and other states for business development and jobs.The state's fiscal woes led Standard & Poor's to downgrade Kansas' credit rating by one notch to AA-minus in July. (Reporting by Karen Pierog in Chicago; Editing by Matthew Lewis)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-sept11-saudi-congress-idUSKCN11R22M	Ryan has concerns over 9/11 Saudi bill but predicts veto override	"
WASHINGTON The U.S. House of Representatives would override any presidential veto of a bill allowing survivors and families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to sue Saudi Arabia
column2: Speaker Paul Ryan predicted on Wednesday while also citing concerns with the legislation.""I worry about legal matters. I worry about trial lawyers trying to get rich off of this. And I do worry about the precedence. At the same time
column3: these victims do need to have their day in court
column4: Ryan
column5: a Republican
column6: told reporters.Congress has overwhelmingly passed the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act in reaction to long-running suspicions
column8: that hijackers of the four U.S. jetliners that attacked the United States in 2001  were backed by the Saudi government. Obama in coming days is expected to veto the bill on grounds that other countries could use the law as an excuse to sue U.S. diplomats
column9: service members or companies. But Congress could have the last word if the Senate and House of Representatives each override that veto by a two-thirds vote.

column1: I do think the votes are there for the override
column2: Ryan said.When asked by a reporter if U.S. support for Saudi Arabia was ""unconditional
column3: Ryan responded that the country ""is a very important and valuable ally"" and is helping Washington in the ""war on terror.""

column1: He noted
column2: however
column3: ""Our support for any country is not unconditional.""

column1: (Reporting By Richard Cowan; Editing by Andrew Hay)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-sept11-saudi-eu-idUSKCN11R26L	European Union asks Obama to stop 9/11 Saudi bill	"
WASHINGTON The European Union on Wednesday called on President Barack Obama to block a U.S. bill allowing survivors and families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to sue Saudi Arabia
column2: saying it was in violation of international law.""The possible adoption and implementation of the (bill) would be in conflict with fundamental principles of international law and in particular the principle of State sovereign immunity
column3: the European Union delegation to the United States said in a letter to the U.S. Department of State seen by Reuters.The letter said the EU considers that the bill's adoption and its implementation could have unwanted consequences
column4: as other states adopt similar legislation. Congress has overwhelmingly passed the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act
column5: known as JASTA
column8: that hijackers of the four U.S. jetliners that attacked the United States in 2001  were backed by the Saudi government.

column1: Obama in coming days is expected to veto the bill on grounds that other countries could use the law as an excuse to sue U.S. diplomats

NEW YORK U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has been a hit with small donors

column3: according to financial disclosures filed on Tuesday. But with the big-money donor class
column4: the players Trump blasted during the primary season as greedy influence peddlers
column5: the celebrity businessman has fallen short of expectations

column7: but Super PAC contributions fell short of expectations. Great America PAC
column8: the pro-Trump Super PAC led by Republican operative Ed Rollins
column9: said in July it expected to pull in more than $20 million by now. Instead
column11: according to the latest campaign finance disclosures. In a similar fashion
column12: a pro-Trump Super PAC kicked off by Los Angeles real estate investor Tom Barrack
column14: said in June it had $32 million in fundraising commitments.But it received just over $2 million that month. A spokesperson for the Super PAC says it has now raised $18 million. It will not file its next report until October 15.  The Republican kingmaker who was expected to be Trump's single biggest backer
column16: has scaled back his initial pledge of $100 million
column17: made in a private meeting with Trump in May
column19: according to two associates close to Adelson familiar with the matter.CLINTON FINANCES

column1: Democrat Hillary Clinton
column2: who will face Trump in the Nov. 8 election
column3: has received about a quarter of her campaign donations from people who contributed $200 or less - $71 million out of a total of $289 million
column4: according to disclosures. Among the biggest backers to the pro-Clinton Super PAC
column5: Priorities USA
column12: executive at SDA Enterprises.Clinton's money advantage will help her fund ad campaigns and get-out-the-vote efforts in the final stretch the 2016 election. She leads Trump by 4 percentage points nationally
column13: according to the latest Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll.Together
column14: Clinton's campaign and Super PAC have raked in a total of $520 million. By comparison
column15: Trump's campaign and two Super PACs backing him have brought in a combined $200 million.Super PACs can raise unlimited money for candidates as long as they don't directly coordinate with the campaign.

column1: The latest filings
column2: which cover spending through August 31
column3: showed a big increase in Trump's spending
column4: with $30 million in disbursements
column5: more than any month so far.They also provided further insight into the stark differences between the two candidates' operations.STARK DIFFERENCES

column1: The Clinton campaign's outlays reflect a traditional presidential playbook
column2: spending five times more than Trump's has on television ads and nine times more on payrolls.The Trump campaign has spent $21 million on online advertising and strategy
column3: $11 million on T-shirts
column4: trucker hats and yard signs
column5: and $4 million on field consulting. Trump recently scored a promise of a $1 million donation from the Ricketts family

column7: but he has yet to see the flurry of large checks that flowed into the coffers of former Republican White House rivals such as Jeb Bush and Ted Cruz. Instead of plowing money into the Trump campaign

column9: the billionaire industrialist Koch Brothers - will focus his efforts and donations on Senate and House of Representatives races

column11: a Republican Super PAC. The Adelsons plan on giving an additional $20 million to the Super PAC that backs Republican House candidates
column12: the sources said.(Corrects date) (Reporting by Michelle Conlin and Grant Smith; Editing by Caren Bohan and Tom Heneghan)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-fda-congress-idUSKCN11R1E4	House committee launches review of FDA criminal office	"
By Sarah N. Lynch
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON A U.S. congressional committee has launched an examination of the Food and Drug Administration's criminal office
column2: raising questions about the unit's management and handling of cases involving food
column3: drugs and devices.The House Energy and Commerce Committee told FDA Commissioner Robert Califf it is ""examining management concerns"" and ""possible morale concerns with the field offices"" of the Office of Criminal Investigations. The September 20 letter
column4: signed by committee chairman Fred Upton and Tim Murphy
column5: chairman of the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
column6: seeks answers to a detailed list of questions by October 12.Among other issues
column7: the House committee questions why George Karavetsos
column10: is allowed to run the unit from an office in South Florida
column11: near his home.An FDA spokeswoman said the agency received the letter and will respond to the committee directly.The House questions come two weeks after Reuters reported how some FDA agents complain criminal office managers have forced them to pursue cases involving mislabeled foreign-imported injectable drugs
column12: at the expense of cases with more potential to protect the public health.Current and former agents complain they have turned into the ""Botox Police
column13: spending thousands of hours chasing doctors who purchased authentic versions of Allergan's anti-wrinkle drug that were labeled for use in other countries.Some agents say their efforts have done little more than protect the pharmaceutical industry's high drug prices in the United States.Those concerns come as the criminal office has had mixed success in bringing cases. From fiscal year 2008-2015
column15: more than half of all opened OCI cases were closed without action.

column1: The House committee asked Califf to explain the process for how criminal cases get opened
column2: and to provide statistics on OCI's arrests
column3: convictions
column4: case initiations and amount of money recovered.Reuters also reported on Karavetsos' relocation to Florida
column5: a move that came less than two years after the FDA paid more than $25
column9: saying statistics are not a fair measure of OCI's success because public health and safety will ""always trump the criminal investigation."" FDA Regulatory Affairs Associate Commissioner Melinda Plaisier defended Karavetsos' move to Miami
column10: saying it was good for the FDA and his family.

column1: The House committee letter also questions how the FDA responded to two prior reports
column2: from the Government Accountability Office and the Health and Human Services Office of the Inspector General
column3: that were critical of the criminal office.The 2012 OIG report cited problems with how the Rockville-based office is run and concluded that field offices ""lack the discretion"" to open cases to address ""food and drug concerns prevalent in their locales.""The report cited a lack of independence within the FDA's criminal office. OCI is housed within the Office of Regulatory Affairs
column4: which is responsible for compliance inspections and helps determine the criminal office's budget. The inspector general recommended structural changes to ""ensure the independence of investigations.""FDA leadership at that time rejected those suggestions.

column1: The criminal office headquarters controls the opening of investigations. Some agents have questioned the office's priorities and say they have
column2: on occasion
column3: been told not to open cases involving other federal agencies.A September 2015 email from Robert West
column4: the recently retired Special Agent in Charge of the Miami field office
column5: is one example.West
column8: the HHS OIG and Homeland Security investigators ""were riding our coattails and were not bringing anything to the table.""Involving those agencies in an investigation from day one
column10: ""is unacceptable.""West previously declined interview requests. Reuters could not immediately reach him Tuesday through an FDA spokeswoman. (Editing by Ronnie Greene)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-china-economy-li-idUSKCN11R02Z	China's premier says U.S. ties will develop no matter who wins election	"
By David Brunnstrom
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK China and the United States will keep developing positive relations no matter who wins November's U.S. presidential election
column2: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang told an economic forum in New York on Tuesday.Li declined to comment on which candidate he favored.Republican Donald Trump has threatened to slap tariffs on Chinese goods and push for tougher trade talks if elected. His Democratic rival
column3: Hillary Clinton
column4: has changed tack on trade
column5: backing away from a Pacific trade pact she previously endorsed.Both candidates have been critical of China's assertive pursuit of territory in the South China Sea
column6: a potential flashpoint in Asia and a cause of significant friction in relations between Washington and Beijing.Li
column7: who was attending the U.N. General Assembly in New York
column8: said the U.S. election was an internal affair for the United States
column9: so what he could say was very limited
column10: but he went on to remark:""No matter who gets elected in the U.S. presidential election
column11: I believe that China-U.S. ties will continue to grow steadily and in a positive direction.""

column1: Li responded to complaints from foreign business leaders about restricted access to the Chinese market by saying that China was open to foreign investment
column2: although some economic sectors were not yet mature.""This process of them becoming more mature is also a process for them to open up and the areas of the Chinese economy open to foreign investment will only increase and China will only open its door even wider. The door will not close
column3: he said.Referring to a U.S.-China Bilateral Investment Treaty that has been long in negotiation given disagreements about access to sectors the sides deem sensitive
column4: Li said as long as both countries took a strong and pragmatic approach
column5: they would be able to reach a mutually beneficial agreement.

column1: As an example of China's willingness to open up its markets
column2: Li said China had decided to designate a Chinese investment bank as a clearing bank for renminbi business in New York and welcomed foreign banks in the city which met eligibility requirements to become clearing banks for the currency.He also said China would soon allow imports of beef on the bone from the United States
column3: now that Chinese quarantine procedures had been completed.Li pledged that China would not engineer a devaluation of its currency to boost exports for its economy
column4: which is growing at its slowest rate in two decades. Some critics in Washington have charged that Beijing is still manipulating its currency
column5: although the U.S. Treasury says its assessment is that it is not undervalued.

column1: China's economy will continue its growth momentum this year
column2: Li said.""I can say here that in the third quarter of this year
column3: or until the end of this year
column4: China's economy will maintain this momentum of steady growth."" China's growth target for this year is 6.5 to 7 percent. In the second quarter of this year
column5: the world's second-largest economy grew 6.7 percent from a year ago
column6: according to official data. (Reporting by David Brunnstrom
column7: David Chance and Rodrigo Campos; Editing by Peter Cooney and Michael Perry)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-un-assembly-obama-idUSKCN11Q22G	Obama urges Israel end occupation and Palestinians accept Israel	"
By Jeff Mason
| UNITED NATIONS
UNITED NATIONS Both sides would benefit if Israel recognized it cannot permanently occupy Palestinian land and if Palestinians rejected incitement and recognized Israel's legitimacy
column2: U.S. President Barack Obama told the United Nations on Tuesday.Obama's efforts to bring about an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement have failed over the nearly eight years he has been in the White House
column3: with the latest push by U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry collapsing in 2014.U.S. officials have held out the possibility Obama could lay out the rough outlines of a deal - ""parameters"" in diplomatic parlance - after the Nov. 8 presidential election and before he leaves office in January
column4: but many analysts doubt this would have much effect.""Surely Israelis and Palestinians will be better off if Palestinians reject incitement and recognize the legitimacy of Israel ...(and if) Israel recognizes that it cannot permanently occupy and settle Palestinian land
column5: Obama said.

column1: Speaking at the General Assembly annual gathering of world leaders at the United Nations for the last time as president
column2: Obama also said Russia was trying to recover ""lost glory"" through force. He warned Russia that if it ""continues to interfere in the affairs of its neighbors
column3: it may be popular at home
column4: it may fuel nationalist fervor for a time
column5: but over time it is also going to diminish its stature and make its borders less secure.""

column1: Russia annexed Ukraine's Crimean peninsula in 2014 after months of protests in Kiev ousted pro-Moscow Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovich.On the international dispute over the South China Sea
column2: Obama said: ""A peaceful resolution of disputes offered by law will mean far greater stability then the militarization of a few rocks and reefs.""

column1: China claims almost all of the South China Sea
column2: through which ships carrying about $5 trillion in trade pass every year. Brunei
column3: Malaysia
column4: the Philippines
column5: Taiwan and Vietnam also have claims in the sea
column6: which is also believed to be rich in energy resources and fish stocks.In July
column7: an arbitration court in The Hague said China's claims to the waterway were invalid
column8: in a case was brought by the Philippines. Beijing has refused to recognize the ruling. (Additional reporting by Arshad Mohammed and Michelle Nichols; Editing by Howard Goller and Grant McCool)"

NEW YORK U.S. President Barack Obama will raise concerns about Israeli settlement activity in Arab lands during a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in New York on Wednesday

I'm sure President Obama will do so tomorrow as well.""
